column60:
the driving force is not likely the energy savings - need to make it fashionable to upgrade - i.e. lifestyle imagery to make it socially valuable to upgrade incorporating the technical/performance features.
 we need to recognize that upgrades can only be mandated at time that some more significant work is done - it's not possible to mandate work be done just for the sake of making energy upgrades - and then, the cost of retrofits can be daunting for homeowners who are generally more interested in the cosmetic and comfort issues than simply performance issues.

column60:
Sounds like my own family/ life situation (though not in Vancouver) so I feel they would act in a manner similar to my own preferences.
 
 Ultimately, I think this family would be interested in upgrades, but also values the savings that a suite would bring. So I think they would invest there first, upgrade to efficient appliances when replacing them (given the payback is reasonable, maybe 10-15 years or less) and then use the additional funds from the rental income for any further energy improvements.

I also would hope that the new owners would have to follow a retrofit code for any upgrades they undertake.

column55: An energy disclosure mandate with a benchmarking, audit, and labeling protocol.,An education campaign for owners and practitioners on potential savings and best practices.,The implementation of a Retrofit Code for energy, emissions, and safety upgrades.
column60:
Story specific: the likely outcome for this house is to upgrade their space heating + DHW systems to electric-based equipment after 2025 when this will be a requirement. The contractor will ideally recommend air tightness and envelope improvements to improve comfort and lower bills. 
 
 General information (not story specific) In the City of Vancouver, we have the mandate and regulation authority to set GHG emissions limits / prescriptive equipment use. Rather than energy efficiency (which Step Code supports, meaning fossil fuels are not diminished at nearly the same rate) we are focused on electrifying mechanical equipment and appliances. With supporting focus on improving the envelope to reduce heating / cooling loads.
 
 So while Vancouver homes will likely not hit high levels of the Step Code, they will achieve significant GHG reductions. 
 
 Near term priorities are 1) create support solutions for those with the highest needs (high energy bills + low income) and 2) public education! Get green-minded people asking for these upgrades.

column54: Heritage character, large, unlikely to be demolished.
column55: An education campaign for owners and practitioners on potential savings and best practices.,Innovative financing mechanisms such as attaching loans to meter savings.,The implementation of a Retrofit Code for energy, emissions, and safety upgrades.
column60:
I foresee a PACE - like property-based financing structure would work well here to facilitate an envelope upgrade paired with a central heating+cooling heat pump system. A 5 head ductless mini-split system could avoid the need for invasive ductwork. The financial benefit from switching from 100% baseboard to 300+% efficient heat pump could provide a quick payback.
 
 A homeowner support tool (online and / or in person) would likely be useful for this couple.

column60:
Don't compare current buildings to a new code like step code that has yet to be proven. 
 There are serious health and safety concerns with the Step code approach that are likely to have negative impacts to occupancy health and well being. The baseline for an existing building is the current energy use from the billing data. There is no benefit to comparing it to Step Code that i can see whatsoever. 
 
 it's also impossible, how do you measure the TEDI of an existing building ?

column54: Systems - though upgraded - are still low performance. Owner's age and financial situation makes retrofit less desirable. I selected 'neutral' in response to that question to reflect a possible opportunity to improve envelope performance when upgrading acoustic performance of the rental suite...and because elderly get cold more easily and retrofit would reduce energy bills - a boomer value (I say that partially tongue-in-cheek, but partly serious). Asbestos remediation might also be a driver, if a suspected connection to a decline in their health...though having lived with it for so long, they would be less motivated, than say a family with kids or expecting. (A transition to entry-level supported living might be more viable, but on the other hand, social isolation is a killer and they sound invested in their community, so would likely be motivated to stay in the neighbourhood). Any helper suite retrofit would likely be piecemeal at best...unless incentives offered to make a comprehensive retrofit viable - a notable 'if'. Given their age and Vancouver's steadily growing demographic and rising inflation, demolition and rebuilding is more likely (unless alternatives incentivized). While the new home may be designed to net zero, the significant expenditure in embodied carbon would negatively impact the critical reductions needed between now and 2030 / 2050.
column55: A public financing scheme such as a provincial 'Green Bank'.,Innovative financing mechanisms such as attaching loans to meter savings.,The creation of an integrated public retrofit servicing agency.
column60:
Not having read this question before responding to the above, I added most of my qualifiers into the previous text response field. As an architect, I would add that while disregarded by many stylistically (for good reason), they can have good bones for modern renovations. That said, these protagonists are very unlikely candidates for such an investment.
 
 Motivation for the three recommended incentive strategies was based on the fact that these protagonists would likely value financial viability and ease of implementation over any others.
 
 Oh, and answers to the 'likeliness of achieving various step code levels by 2035' question reflect responses to subsequent questions about retrofit likelihood. (I had initially filled them out negating these factors, but that would seem to lessen the value of the speculative exercise). A prompt to confirm what you're looking for there would help respondents put any doubts to rest.

column54: The protagonists' demographic (being parents with wide age spread and young family), their relative financial comfort (affluence via stability if not number of zeros), their investment in the house (valuing its design and caring enough to maintain it...and even enjoying the DIY aspect), and their desire to stay in a good neighbour as their kids grow, and the many options such a property affords to accommodating shifting living structures as they get old and their kids grow up (i.e. they could subdivide the house for one of their kid's family, and another could live in a new laneway house in the spacious back yard)
column55: A public financing scheme such as a provincial 'Green Bank'.,Aggregation of individual retrofit projects into packages.,Conventional financing mechanism such as grants or tax abatements.
column60:
Given their ecological ethics, and the wife research background (as a journalist) and the husband's interest (and likely growing competence and confidence) in DIY projects, I expect they would already be hip to the need to improve their home's energy performance; and would do their own research to get up to speed on things they needed to do.
 
 Given their financial stability, they are not hand to mouth, so would likely be well-served by a more conventional 'green grant' , 'green loan' mechanism. 
 
 Given the husband's DIY interests, the coupling of retrofits into packages would be a more satisfying (and more effective) way for them to get further faster. The uprooting chaos of a comprehensive retrofit would be daunting thought with 2-3 small kids (and even more so with one in the oven); and an unstructured one-by-one approach could mean they would be in perpetual reno mode - also chaotic and stressful.
 
 The 'best practices' component of the education campaign did give me pause, if this included DIY How-tos. Though again, given the husband's comfort in this space as outlined, I imagine they could figure this out on their own on-line and with the occasional help line chat with a seasoned Home Depot employee.

column13: The most important trait of Kevin and Iris as a couple is, in their own words, their commitment to ‘sustainable living’. They own a Tesla Model 3, but more often than not use bikes for commuting. They not only designed and built their home, but did so to make it highly energy-efficient.
column54: Given the description, I envision any renovations being dependent on incentives (and / or combination of incentives and social competition / shaming). The stepped responses in 'likeliness' reflect suspected CBA evaluation thresholds. Given air leakage, I could imagine them springing for an airtightness retrofit as the most economical option if they could do only one thing. If incentives compelling enough (and / or social shaming great enough) I imagine this would motivate greater retrofit investments. And that, if they were doing it, I imagine the would see the value in doing this all at once - because this is cheaper in the long run (as any Civil Engineer would know). ...and no one wants their mother-in-law nagging about the renos not being done yet, or about the shame they are forced to suffer because theirs is the worst performing house of anyone in her bridge club.
column55: An energy disclosure mandate with a benchmarking, audit, and labeling protocol.,Conventional financing mechanism such as grants or tax abatements.,Innovative financing mechanisms such as attaching loans to meter savings.
column60:
Given their financial affluence and their most likely retrofit motivators being incentives and social status, conventional financing mechanisms and mandated public disclosure seem the most likely triggers.
 
 I could imagine attaching loans to meter savings being an added bonus (perhaps more psychological than fiscal) for the civil engineer husband as performance analytics teachable-moments with his son. 
 
 Anecdotal aside supporting the latter: 
 M father is a PEng. Though not motivated by eco-social ethics (at least not until my daughter turned three and started scolding him for not), after he got his Nest thermostat, he became a highly competitive energy conservation ambassador. (Literally emailing us his Nest reports and letting us know how much he 'beat' his neighbour Joe by).

column60:
Energy is cheap, retrofitting a building envelope is not. A robust building envelope retrofit is required, as well as adding heat recovery to ventilation. This would be very expensive and not financially attractive in terms of payback on investment. I don't see a way to force people to make such large renovations to their homes unless it is heavily subsidized, and even then people may not do it unless it will overall save them money, or even if it did, simply because they don't know about these things and are hesitant to pursue such a big and disruptive renovation. Not to mention the risks of discovering other costs for upgrades once the retrofit starts.
 
 I think it's far more likely that the property would achieve high performance through being torn down and rebuilt, at which time it would be subject to high performance standards. This seems more likely to me due to the land value.

column54: Achieving Step 3 or greater would require improved air tightness and most importantly, central ventilation through an HRV. Adding HRV ducting to an existing home seems unlikely to me. In addition, the home would require major updates to the building envelope thermal performance as well as air tightness. I don't believe these are likely to happen due to the cost

At some point it is easier and more cost effective to replace the home entirely, which seems more likely with the land prices in Vancouver, particularly if this home on a large lot is replaced with a duplex or other more dense housing.

It's important to consider economic viability and social equity in developing related policies or incentives.
 
 
 Repeated from input above:
 Economic incentives through allowing additional living space/suite when retrofitted to Step 5.There's opportunity for co-benefits with improving seismic resilience and housing affordability. Allowing two or more adjacent buildings to be retrofitted into a rowhouse strata, adding "infill units" in between the original houses i.e. turning side yards into small homes.We'll then only need to "upgrade" the exterior walls along the front and back of the buildings and extend them to close off the sideyards.There would not be a need to upgrade the side walls between the existing buildings. The additional small homes created will be an economic incentive to make the Step 5 retrofits viable.

column54: I assume the house would be torn down and re-built within 5-7 years due to age of building/system and occupants (father likely passed away, son likely moved out). Under existing/anticipated policy within this timeframe, gas heating is still allowed, and fossil gas has artificially low rates due to subsidization of the industry. Therefore, with higher costs of heat pumps, there is no major driver to go zero carbon at this time. On the other hand, as the family is environmentally minded they may choose this direction.

column60: Incentives are fine as supporting mechanisms but ultimately we need clear regulation to get off fossil fuels. Also there is often conflation of energy efficiency with GHG reduction. Energy efficiency alone is not enough to reduce CO2 in line with CoV's new climate commitments.

column54: Seems unlikely this family will live in the same house for 30 years, and/or significantly invest in upgrades, therefore demolish/rebuild either under their ownership or another seems likely. Whether or not it is carbon neutral depends mostly on when it rebuilds and what the city policy is at that time.

column54: The family likely won't be able to finance a major retrofit, and sounds like they may be there for the long term. Achieving Step 5 would require a major building renovation including envelop, which is a very expensive investment that doesn't see a payback.
column55: A public financing scheme such as a provincial 'Green Bank'.,Innovative financing mechanisms such as attaching loans to meter savings.,The implementation of a Retrofit Code for energy, emissions, and safety upgrades.

column54: If the couple downsizes after the kids move out in the next 10 years, the house will likely be rebuilt (since it's in Shaughnessy, the added cost of rebuilding would be relatively small compared to the price of the property). If regulations require high efficiency new builds, the house could achieve high levels on the Step Code.
column55: Conventional financing mechanism such as grants or tax abatements.,The creation of an integrated public retrofit servicing agency.,The implementation of a Retrofit Code for energy, emissions, and safety upgrades.
column60: Like most existing buildings, the cost of retrofitting the building to achieve Step 5 would probably be better spent rebuilding the house with passive features incorporated. You can't retrofit the shape of a house to optimize window placement to catch light and wind. If Part 9 Code requires "passive ready" design, it's more likely a house will be carbon neutral by 2050.
